text: I have seen a lot of comments regarding the dual casting of Paul Dano and John Cusack.  A few things. Prettty evident that Paul Dano looks a like Brian in the 1960's. And John Cusack does resemble Brian a bit from the 1980's. Remember, the current day Brian, at age 72 is not being portrayed in the movie. The director, Bill Polhad is showing that the Brian Wilson of the 1980's and early 1990's having survived the torture of "Dr." Gene Landy, came out a COMPLETELY DIFFERENT person than the Brian Wilson of the 1960's. Using a different actor, who can capture the tics and off beat mannerisms of Brian Wilson is paramount to acheive that effect. Go with it.

text: Hard to imagine Cusack as Brian, but it was great to hear he has the reverance from a sweet sit-in on a recent @Nerdist podcast.  I hope this film reaches far and wide in a way so many other made-for-TV Brian/Beach Boys biopics may not have been able to.  Maybe a new generation can discover the wonder of Brian and his heart.  It's wild to think about how someone basically evil like Landy by all means should have destroyed this legend, but perhaps through the good grace of the universe Brian has been allowed (however fractured) to endure in a world that can always use more pure souls. Can't wait to see this!

text: I saw the movie.  it left me so sad.  I wish they had shown how well Brian's life turned out and how well he is doing today.  John Cusack acted well but really, I don't think he looks like Brian or embodies him... they could have found someone better for the role.   They got Mike Love dead on.     In the movie, the music is very much of secondary importance and I wish they had given us more of the beauty of his music.  It is such a sad story and hard to believe that Brian's family never saw what was happening with him and didn't get him to qualified doctors.  Especially since they had the money to get him the best medical care anywhere in the country.  It was up to the maid and a new acquaintance to get Brian the help he needed.   Why is it that stars in California so often seem to be surrounded by people who don't care about them as human beings and sycophants?

text: Does EVERY biopic have to have the same scene where somebody delivers the most pedantic, obvious line about what a crazy, mad genius the main character is? author: Rumalo M

text: This is how I felt about the movie: If _Wouldn't It Be Nice: My Own Story_ was Dr. Landy's spin on a Brian Wilson biography, _Love and Mercy_ was Melinda's spin. I have never understood why Melinda makes a point of insisting Brian isn't a paranoid schizophrenic. I mean, fine, maybe he isn't. BUT, if the guy hears voices in his head, and believes bizarre things for no logical reason, schizophrenia is NOT an unreasonable diagnosis! He has _some_ psychotic disorder or another. Here's the problem: There is already too much stigma associated with mental illness as it is. As a society, we barely tolerate people who have chronic depression. We can _kinda_ understand bipolar disorder (which is a psychotic disorder). But as soon as anybody says "psychosis", or the dreaded "schizo-[anything]", suddenly we're all fair game for mockery and distrust. If Brian Wilson has a psychotic disorder, and Melinda is obscuring the truth of that, she's prolonging the stigma.

text: By
author: Kelly Cecelia Glick

text: We have waited so very long for this. A lifetime really. Over the years that we waited, Brian Wilson's soul was made something like a meal for two man-eating monsters. First his late father Murry. Then the mad witch doctor Eugene Landy.  John Cusak has never been so riveting as Damaged Brian in the 80s. Paul Dano gently slaps us into a memory of the little-boyness of Brian in the moments when we had our first Beach Boy listens.   And later on the rescue--by the one who may have been Brian's Jesus. Or Mary perhaps. A seller of cars named Melinda Ledbetter. Conjured in the dazzling way of Elizabeth Banks.   The story unfolds in a way that made this viewer wonder how so much sadness might have been saved if we could only have born witness sooner.  The Gorgeous and the Awful live here as high-voltage neighbors. The perfect splash of the sun and the unseen closed-door Wilson family hurricane. We hear a semblance of the voices--both crazed and meticulously melodic--that played in Brian's skull for decades. And still play--in perhaps softer stanzas--to this day.  We're taken back to a late California night when the veteran session drummer Hal Blaine tells Brian that even though he's worked and played with Sinatra, Dean Martin, Phil Spector and so many more, that he hears in Brian's music strokes of genius not found before.   We get to eavesdrop as the Beach Boys talk about keeping up with the Beatles in the moment of Rubber Soul. We're in on the birth of Brian's "pocket symphony"-- the one that made house calls at nine studios before it was a wrap--called Good Vibrations.   We hear Boy Brian move into deeper water...and "Surf''s Up."   As the warm season peaks again over America, we at long last get a seat near the stage of the Endless Summer.  Too close not to be stunned by the golden hue of the glory. And too near to miss the jab of the deep blue of the often terrible hurt.
author: jim bleikamp

text: Salut à tous.Je viens de voir le film(I'm french). Je suis un grand fan de Brian Wilson, un grand génie de la musique !. Une des plus belles biopics jamais vue !. Mais, quelle idée fatale de prendre DEUX acteurs différents pour un seul rôle ?. Lorsque je vois l'immense Paul Dano, il me faut une minute pour voir Brian Wilson. Mais, lorsque je vois John Cusack (que j'aime beaucoup, mais ce n'est pas la question) je vois .... John Cusack !. Mais qui a eu cette idée ???. Surtout que de nos jours, c'est très facile de vieillir un acteur, plus que jamais !!!. Ray, Tina, Jim Morrison, Elvis, Edith Piaf, James Brown etc .... Au moins, c'était linéaire dans le jeu des acteurs .... Ici, l'impression de voir deux films, deux histoires parallèles certes, mais deux histoires différentes !. En fait, il faudra toujours expliquer aux jeunes, qui verront ce film, et qui ne connaissent pas Brian Wilson, que c'est la même personne, la même histoire !!!.Quelle erreur, quel fatal gâchis !!.Pour conclure, un grand respect pour Paul Giamatti, quel acteur effrayant de talent !!! :).Et la superbe Elisabeth Banks, quel jeu délicat, une immense actrice que je découvre, elle n'a pas besoin de parler, on vois, on lis ses sentiments dans ses expressions, un livre ouvert, c'est très rare ....!!!. C'était un film à Oscars, mais cette histoire de casting sur un seul personnage, à tout fait rater !!!. Mais regardez-ce film, oui, pour ces acteurs, et surtout pour Brian Wilson et sa musique !!!! !.Peace.:)

text: I give it a 7/10, realistically. There is an ever so slight lack of emotion in contrast to the volatile nature of things, and the movie feels very condensed. Perhaps, without revealing any spoilers, because scenes depicting him in 3 stages of his life, from young to old are all juxtaposed in and only serve as a passing thought, like a reference of convenience,used to facilitate the true character of the movie, his mental illness. I'm still a fan of long, epic sagas, from coming of age to the meat and bones of the story and continuing on to a climactic happy or tragic ending, respectively. A beginning, a middle and an end. This feels like we missed the first few episodes, but it manages to do it with a little grace. They should have added another 45 minutes to this movie.

text: I've just seen this movie hours ago and I'm still blown away. Seriously, this movie is a masterpiece of narrative, acting and emotion. The whole cast is terrific, but Paul Dano gives one the best performances I've seen in the whole year. For real, he was snubbed by the Oscars for There will be blood but snubbing him away would be unforgivable. He gives such a real, complex and brutally honest performance of someone alienated and haunted by his own disease but also someone naive and innocent who's manipulated. It's a character you can feel real, you feel sorry for him but also you can relate to his pain and most of all you feel so powerless. You want to save him all the time and at the same time you can see he's a genius. It's truly a depth and unique performance that cannot be missed. Same with Elizabeth Banks, always underrated, who makes something amazing with an "easy" role. She's not only the love interest, she gives her character a charisma and an strenght trought the whole movie wich also deserves a nomination. She really captures that feeling of trying desperatly to save someone you love, the frustation of being unable to do anything. Cusack is fantastic too, like a little, innocent boy in the body of an old, beated man.  This movie is outstanding in so many ways, really shows what it is to isolated and misunderstood. The acting, the editing, the soundtrack...one of the best movies I've seen recently.
author: PalmurcioWorld

author: CPO Durnell

text: Honestly I think this is the best biopic I have ever seen, and I have seen a lot, especially of rock stars. I was initially skeptical because of the Dano/Cusack split but the director explained it in a way that seemed brilliant --- basically the "Paul Dano Brian" disappeared when he "went to bed" (had his mental breakdown and became a recluse for years), and the person who eventually emerged from the heartbreak and wreckage was a different person, symbolized by the switch to Cusack as older Brian. We all know that Dano, already a phenomenal actor at such a young age, hits a home run here, nailing every aspect of the young Brian, his walk, his slouch (he was self-conscious as he stood 6'3"), the patterns of his speech. But I have to say that Cusack does some of the very best acting of his career in this film. I had forgotten honestly that he can act with such subtlety and conviction. He gets at the "soul" of the later Brian, a man who has experienced tremendous loss, in a more quiet way than Dano, and it is also brilliant and devastating. Banks is also excellent -- she conveys a tremendous amount of strength and integrity as an ordinary woman caught up in an extraordinary story.

text: Everyone needs to ease up on Mike Love.  I’m no fan, never have been, by a long shot but you should give credit where it’s due.  Mike was a key factor and effective front man in the gelling of the Beach Boys image during those the early years.  But his personality soon came into a somewhat one-sided conflict with Brian who was focused on the music and not the fame.  Their relationship wasn’t too unlike that of Lennon and McCartney;  talent versus ego, vision versus formula, popularity versus vilification (thank God there wasn’t a Yoko factor).  I'm sure Love realized he could never compete on a level playing field with the sheer musical talent of Brian Wilson - who could?  But it was their complimentary synergies that defined the Beach Boys Part I before it was even possible for Brian Wilson to evolve into Beach Boys Part 2 and beyond.  From another perspective, you could say Mike Love helped take over the reins of the touring Beach Boys at a critical juncture while the writing/producing Beach Boy (Wilson) could stay back and experiment with new sounds, innovation and production.  Regardless, Mike Love’s presence was there the whole time and no one, not even Love or Wilson, knows what songs might have been written - or not been written - if he hadn’t been there.  Mike has also suffered from being a relatively unlikeable showoff whereas Brain has a modest presence that makes his talent all the more mysterious and empathic.   As much as I dearly love Pet Sounds, I also love The Beach Boys, Today!  And my favorite song of all time, “Kiss Me, Baby” was written by Brian Wilson and Mike Love.  For that fact alone, I’m glad there was a Mike Love.

text: As I write this Brian Wilson my favorite musician singer songwriter is playing at Symphony Hall Boston Two nights he was sold out then he heads for Tanglewood I am so upset I tried everything to get seats .The prices were outrageous. That were left up until today.l was a musician drummer guitar and as a teenager the harmony of the brothers  Carl and Dennis Am Jardine and last and least Mike I saw them in 1964 In Providence and many times after but Brian replaced after that by Bruce Johnston l. even met Bruce talked to All Mike Dennis was five feet away from me at Providence College ..He hitchhiked from Boston was at a live recorded concert in Foxboro they played until one in the morning .Then fifteen years ago I took my son to see Brian at Symphony Hallhe loved it as much as me Tears ran down my face as he played my favorite songs in that beautiful hall many Pet Sounds songs hardly any car or surf songs the songs I loved that you never heard on the radio .After Dennis who to me was the California Beat and a beautiful scrappy soulful voice epitomised  California  and Carl the souful voice and falsetto of an angel .Next to Brian's falsetto the best Pet Sounds my favorite album of all time filled me with joy hope and made me cry in joy not sorrrow lyrics notes sounds music that took you out of this world 50 years old I had the original lp I was thirteen Like Brian I had a connection I had an abusive father and developed a mental illness which has stollen most of my life That made me appreciate the life and film of a true genius and most of all Brian's music Which lifted me up and made me go on So to see Brian performing Pet Sounds a true blessing from God and we both survived and got  well at least we survived So All YOU BRIAN WILSON FANS LUCKY ENOUGH TO SEE HIM PERFORM AT SYMPHONY HALL CHERISH IT BECAUSE HE TRULY IS A GIFT OF LOVE FROM GOD WE WILL NEVER SEE AGAIN.Hopefully  I may get to see him in Hartford in September. So to all you Brian Wilson fans God Bless you because we are blessed in our time to have a genius like Brian .

author: Aleister Crowly

text: I saw this in June 2015 and sat electrified in the theater...best movie of 2015.  Dano literally BECOMES Brian Wilson on the screen and nails his personality in an oscar-worthy performance. Cusack is also quite good as older Brian but Paul Dano steals the show with a masterful performance.  Banks, Giamatti, and Jake Abel as Mike Love were also very effective. This movie captures two periods of Brian's life with much depth and feeling and great attention to detail in the 1960's segments. Watching Brian work his musical genius in the studio while making Pet Sounds and Good Vibrations is a treat to watch. You don't have to be a Beach Boys fan to love this movie.  It is a great human drama and a must-see for everyone.
author: BloozeDaddy

text: The performances in this movie by Cusack and Dano weren't about "looking like" Brian Wilson.  The performances are about convincingly telling Wilson's story, and I must say that I had always loved Beach Boys music, but I had no idea of how tortured Wilson's life (and, his brothers') had been with a cruel and abusive upbringing.   How any of these wonderful voices found a reason to sing is beyond me, much less create.  Wilson's artistic range is beyond my understanding and both Cusack and Dano deserve recognition for their impressive performances, rather than criticism for failing to "look like" the man that they each portrayed.

author: Debajyoti Guha

text: My dad absolutely loved the Beach Boys. Saw them numerous times. I thought this would be the perfect movie to see with him when he was battling lung cancer in the spring of 2015, to get his mind off the pain. But his response when I shared the trailer with him was, "Looks sad." Sadly we never did see it together, and we lost him on July 10th, 2015. I still have never watched this, but just added it to my Watchlist playlist, because whenever I think of the Beach Boys, I think of Dad. "God only knows what I'd be without you", Dad. Thanks for 29 great years. See you on the other side
author: Benjamin Selander

text: Loved John Cusack's portrayal of Brian.  Very gentle and believable.  Elizabeth Banks' empathetic performance was equally moving.  Paul Dano's "Pet Sounds" sessions were fascinating and Paul Giamatti as Dr. Landy was downright scary.  Really enjoyed the depth this movie offered and have subsequently watched numerous interviews and concerts.  Such a lovely soul.  Glad he's with Melinda.
author: S. Pohl

text: This film was soooo good and so overlooked when it finally got released.

text: Dano looks more like Brian but Cusack claimed his essence and mannerisms beautifully.  Both actors were SUPERB.

text: Paul Dano was great, but Cusack isn't a good fit for this kind of role. He is far more convincing as an actor when he portrays pompous, self-centered jackasses. And I'm not saying that to be mean, it's just the type of actor he is. He's good in other movies. But here? No.

text: This movie doesn't do justice to the subject. Wasted opportunity. Emotionally somewhat feeble, not dramatic enough, not enough tension. The makers of this movie presume too much foreknowledge. If you don't know much of the BB's/BW history you are completely lost. The only good thing here is Paul Dano, but John Cusack is totally miscast.

text: My favorite rock biopic. Dano and Cusack did wonderful jobs. And the real Brian Wilson was on set during the filming. I especially liked how the picture was made like a docudrama and not like a musical like Rocketman.
author: Elisa Smith

text: This movie was Sad about mainly Brian's life with the drugs and mental problems. And it was hard to figure out which actors were playing the Beach Boys in the movie. I clearly know who Brian was as well as Mike Love, but the others I could not figure out as the movie played. saw it last night on Hulu. I never knew Brian's life was this complicated. And with Most movies like this that you see these days, the actors did not even look close to the real people in the band. Mike Love stood out the best when they picked the actor for this movie. I read years ago that Brian was actually held captive by a doctor that kept him away from close friends and family, right? That part of the movie I got. But the rest of it was too much going back and forth from childhood to present day. And was actually confusing to watch at times. I guess I was expecting more of a Beach Boys movie from beginning to end of their careers. But now I know it was mainly about Brian's problems. Again, Sad life he had. BTW....Book em Dano!
author: JPC
